title: Crossbeam above twenty cubits
vignette: Neighbors install a beam over their alley entrance to permit carrying on rest day. They realize it sits higher than twenty cubits.

options.text: Lower the beam; current placement is invalid.
Leave it; height doesn't matter if walls are sturdy.

title: Resident omitted from courtyard shared boundary setup
vignette: Ten families share a courtyard but one traveler forgot to contribute bread for the shared boundary setup. rest day begins before he returns.

options.text: Everyone may carry if the traveler relinquishes his rights.
No carrying until a valid shared boundary setup includes all residents.

title: Shared boundary setup distance extension eaten by animals
vignette: Ruth placed food at the city edge to walk farther on rest day. Before sundown, dogs ate the food but she only discovers later.

options.text: She may walk the extended distance since the shared boundary setup existed at twilight.
Her shared boundary setup is void so she must stay within the regular limit.

title: Shared boundary setup bread baked by a non-Jew
vignette: The community used loaves purchased from a outsider bakery for their courtyard shared boundary setup. Some question if that disqualifies it.

options.text: It is valid; ownership matters more than who baked it.
Invalid; the bread must be made by Jews.

title: One shared boundary setup for two festival days
vignette: A two-day holiday falls on Thursday and Friday. May a single shared boundary setup distance extension cover both days?

options.text: Yes; prepare one shared boundary setup for the entire span.
No; each day requires its own shared boundary setup.

title: Shared boundary setup placed just beyond the boundary
vignette: Measuring after sunset reveals the food was a few cubits past the 2000 limit.

options.text: Rely on the initial measurement; the intent was valid.
The shared boundary setup fails; stay within the standard travel zone.

title: Using a live animal as a wall
vignette: To complete their enclosure, they tether a camel to act as the fourth wall of a booth.

options.text: Permissible; any sturdy barrier counts.
Not acceptable since it might wander.

title: Shared boundary setup made with spoiled bread
vignette: The only bread available was already moldy. They used it anyway to set an shared boundary setup.

options.text: It works so long as dogs would still eat it.
Spoiled food cannot establish an shared boundary setup.

title: Joining houses through a window
vignette: Two homes share a small window but no door between them. Can they join via shared boundary setup to carry items through?

options.text: Yes; a window connection suffices.
No; only a full doorway allows merging.

title: Late travelers relying on an shared boundary setup
vignette: A group sets out before sundown but delays and only places their shared boundary setup after dark.

options.text: Count it; they intended before nightfall.
Too late; traveling farther is prohibited.

title: Guardian setting an shared boundary setup for a child
vignette: A father places food for his young son so the boy can walk farther on rest day.

options.text: Valid; a guardian may act on behalf of minors.
Invalid; only adults establish their own shared boundary setup.

title: Alley open on one side
vignette: An alley bordered by houses on three sides opens directly to a field. Is a side-post enough to permit carrying?

options.text: Yes; a single side-post makes it a proper alley.
No; such an open alley can never be permitted.

title: Rooftops of unequal height
vignette: Residents want to treat adjacent flat roofs at different levels as one domain for carrying.

options.text: They combine if within ten handbreadths.
Different heights keep them separate.

title: Shared boundary setup stored in a cracked jar
vignette: The bread was placed in a jug that later shattered but still partly holds the loaf.

options.text: It's fine; the container still functions.
No; an intact vessel is required.

title: Village absorbed by a growing city
vignette: New houses now link a small village to the nearby town. Do their travel zone limits merge?

options.text: Yes; treat them as one community.
No; the village retains its own boundary.
